goals.question: What is the correlation between x and y for each dataset?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of x and y for each dataset
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the relationship between x and y for each dataset. It can help to determine if there is a linear relationship or if there are any outliers that may affect the correlation.

goals.question: What is the mean and standard deviation of x and y for each dataset?
goals.visualization: Box plot of x and y for each dataset
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the distribution of x and y for each dataset. It can help to determine if the data is normally distributed or if there are any outliers that may affect the mean and standard deviation.

goals.question: What is the relationship between x and y for each dataset?
goals.visualization: Line plot of x and y for each dataset
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the trend of x and y for each dataset. It can help to determine if there is a linear relationship or if there are any patterns that may affect the relationship.

goals.question: What is the distribution of x and y for each dataset?
goals.visualization: Histogram of x and y for each dataset
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the distribution of x and y for each dataset. It can help to determine if the data is normally distributed or if there are any outliers that may affect the distribution.

goals.question: What is the relationship between x and y for each dataset?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of x and y for each dataset with a regression line
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the relationship between x and y for each dataset. It can help to determine if there is a linear relationship or if there are any outliers that may affect the correlation. The regression line can also help to predict future values of y based on x.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="ticks")
    sns.lmplot(x="x", y="y", col="dataset", hue="dataset", data=data,
               col_wrap=2, ci=None, palette="muted", height=4,
               scatter_kws={"s": 50, "alpha": 1})
    plt.subplots_adjust(top=0.8)
    plt.suptitle("What is the correlation between x and y for each dataset?", wrap=True)
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="ticks")
    sns.boxplot(x="dataset", y="x", data=data, palette="Set3")
    plt.title("What is the mean and standard deviation of x and y for each dataset?", wrap=True)
    plt.show()
    sns.set(style="ticks")
    sns.boxplot(x="dataset", y="y", data=data, palette="Set3")
    plt.title("What is the mean and standard deviation of x and y for each dataset?", wrap=True)
    plt.show()
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="ticks")
    sns.set_palette("husl")
    g = sns.FacetGrid(data, col="dataset", hue="dataset", col_wrap=2, height=4)
    g.map(sns.lineplot, "x", "y", marker="o")
    g.set_axis_labels("X", "Y")
    g.fig.suptitle("What is the relationship between x and y for each dataset?", y=1.05)
    plt.subplots_adjust(top=0.85)
    plt.legend(title="Dataset", loc="upper right")
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="whitegrid")
    g = sns.FacetGrid(data, col="dataset", hue="dataset", col_wrap=2, height=4)
    g.map(sns.histplot, "x", kde=False, bins=10)
    g.map(sns.histplot, "y", kde=False, bins=10)
    g.fig.subplots_adjust(top=0.8)
    g.fig.suptitle('What is the distribution of x and y for each dataset?')
    plt.legend(title='Dataset', loc='upper right')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```
